pt: {sc}frank{/sc} {sc}candid{/sc} {sc}open{/sc} {sc}plain{/sc} mean showing willingness to tell what one feels or thinks. {sc}frank{/sc} stresses lack of shyness or secretiveness or of evasiveness from considerations of tact or expedience.
{sc}candid{/sc} suggests expression marked by sincerity and honesty especially in offering unwelcome criticism or opinion.
{sc}open{/sc} implies frankness but suggests more indiscretion than {sc}frank{/sc} and less earnestness than {sc}candid{/sc}.
{sc}plain{/sc} suggests outspokenness and freedom from affectation or subtlety in expression.

{sc}liable{/sc} {sc}open{/sc} {sc}exposed{/sc} {sc}subject{/sc} {sc}prone{/sc} {sc}susceptible{/sc} {sc}sensitive{/sc} mean being by nature or through circumstances likely to experience something adverse. {sc}liable{/sc} implies a possibility or probability of incurring something because of position, nature, or particular situation.
{sc}open{/sc} stresses a lack of barriers preventing incurrence.
{sc}exposed{/sc} suggests lack of protection or powers of resistance against something actually present or threatening.
{sc}subject{/sc} implies an openness for any reason to something that must be suffered or undergone.
{sc}prone{/sc} stresses natural tendency or propensity to incur something.
{sc}susceptible{/sc} implies conditions existing in one's nature or individual constitution that make incurrence probable.
{sc}sensitive{/sc} implies a readiness to respond to or be influenced by forces or stimuli.

et: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old High German {it}offan{/it} open, Old English {it}ūp{/it} up
shortdef: having no enclosing or confining barrier : accessible on all or nearly all sides
being in a position or adjustment to permit passage : not shut or locked
having a barrier (such as a door) so adjusted as to allow passage
